msg types; we need to support msg types like application/x-www-form-urlencoded (see https://api.slack.com/slash-commands).

we also need to support passing parameters via the querystring.

event payload:
i think we should consider having some canonical attributes, such as 
- event source type
- event source instance guid
- timestamp
- maybe more

we need to investigate how this ca be realized without changing the msg payload coming from the source (we need to expect people will want to reuse existing code snippets for parsing the webhook msg)

You are right. My original intent was to get our deployment to work on ansible. We were very far into development when we noticed blackbox and ios sdks were missing. We did not stumble across this earlier because there was no test for their existence. When I finally got my PR ready I was asked to move blackbox to open, which I did.

We just announced the shift to ansible today, however there will be a grace period of a few weeks where both ant and ansible deployments are supported as we iron out all of the little cracks and tweaks we have in the mess that is ant right now. So your work is not in vain, we still need ant for the time being.

I also agree PRs should not stay open for so long.

Great.  Changes look good.

Note that this is "yet another action" which will run only for the maximum time of an action, which is 5 minutes currently. That won't be a suitable mechanism to provide an RSS feed which needs to generate events over days/weeks/months?
We previously preferenced python for the task of replacing our bash scripts. I personally found it way easier to write little scripts in python due to the non-async nature of the language.

We should extend that split to all our actioncontainers maybe? Only having it in nodejs feels like adding a lot of maintainability and build-process overhead to just installing one package in the same image? Shouldn't stuff like "imagemagick" be in every actionContainer we have?

Is there a reason to continue to execute tests via ant?
Not really. Just not in scope for this issue. Needs to be swapped to gradle on all other occasions as well.

to list feeds, a developer using whisk should _never_ have to know that feeds are implemented as actions (actions are just impl choices). an event provider creating feeds has to know that, but not a regular user.

i'd suggest to either expose feeds as a first class entity or allow listing them with a parameter to `wsk package list`, eg `wsk package list -feeds`

> they can all have a "don't prompt me, i know what i'm doing" switch though.

negative.

in the future - first, i want us to remove the cloudant and couch specific config files (no longer necessary).
this will consolidate the db configuration for couch (and its variants).
This is the action, no installation etc? Is that intentional? Also, should this be part of openwhisk or its own rss whisk package?
Is the goal to include this as part of the openwhisk repository or a standalone repository?

Should this be in openwhisk at all?
I think this looks good to merge, I think setting the env variable in docker.sh and make it available for all users is the right approach.

With the new vagrant setup we need it to configure wsk cli PATH for root in addition of vagrant user, and it's currently setup in /etc/environment because the wsk cli it's executed as part of the vagrant provisioning.
Also I think we lost tab completion configuration with the transition to new vagrant flow, I think we need to restore that in addition to start thinking on providing a autocomplete bash for go-cli

IMO, the question for this package, like a few others in various stages of progress, is it something that is considered an essential package that would/could be leveraged by many customer/user scenarios or demos; if so, then they should be installed as part of the "core" system to make it useful (apart from system, utils) out-of-the-box.

copy and paste from @domdom82 

we just discussed a possible solution for the issue:
1. remove initdb mode
2. move create immortal db stuff to common initdb.yml that gets included by both cloudant and couch roles
3. initdb.yml does this:

```
1. check if subjects db exists
2. if yes, do nothing
3. if no, create it. add initial keys
```

This way there is no way ever that a user can accidentally drop subjects db by means of our playbooks.
If the user really wants to drop the subjects db, they have to manually log into cloudant and manually drop it there. No automatic way exists anymore.

Another pull will be on the go...

@markusthoemmes With [shelljs](https://www.npmjs.com/package/shelljs) you write the scripts in a non-async way, that's why their are easy. 

Like

```
require 'shelljs/global'

if (exec `wsk action install ${CATALOG_HOME}/slack/post.js" slack/post`).code != 0
  echo 'Error: wsk commit failed'
  exit 1
```

In summary both python and nodejs can be use to write synchronous looking scripts.
My team is more familiar with nodejs, but with wsk we are getting familiar with all programming languages ðŸ˜¸
This was merged with #564.

Hum `wsk package list` feels wrong, this command it's about listing only packages, `wsk package get $name` or `wsk package get $name --summary` it's about list the package content.

This will get you the summary of the specified package like:

```
$ wsk package get myGit --summary
package /csantana@us.ibm.com_dev/myGit
 feed   /csantana@us.ibm.com_dev/myGit/webhook: Creates a webhook on github to be notified on selected changes
```

What about `wsk list` listing feeds?

Today it `wsk list` prints a summary for `packages` `actions` `triggers` and `rules` but it doesn't list `feeds`

for example the `feed` `/csantana@us.ibm.com_dev/myGit/webhook`
Can be listed very easily with `wsk list` like this:

```
$ wsk list
```

entities in namespace: csantana@us.ibm.com_dev
**packages**
/csantana@us.ibm.com_dev/myGit                                    private binding
**actions**
/csantana@us.ibm.com_dev/echo                                     private
**triggers**
/csantana@us.ibm.com_dev/myGitTrigger                             private
**rules**
/csantana@us.ibm.com_dev/ifGitThenEcho                            private
**feeds**
/csantana@us.ibm.com_dev/myGit/webhook                                   private

@rabbah For now we are accepting all new catalog content into this repo under the catalog folder, eventually will move into [openwhisk-openwhisk-catalog](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk-catalog) repo when the whole folder get's moved out.

This is an action, that tries to read from an rss feed? Like @markusthoemmes said this is an action that get's killed by the time it tries to do something.

I don't think this is the goal, the goal is to provide a way to provide a openwhisk feed that it's implemented as a long running deamon/app that users can create triggers with configurations options like the url, they want their trigger to be fire when there is a new rss item added to the rss feed.

There are other packages however (eg push notification) that are already in a different repo. Why not do it for this as well? We can move the discussion elsewhere.

As for this pr, it's not complete - not clear if this is a feed or just an action? no installation script. no tests.

we should document the `git clone` and `install.sh` steps for external packages and not install them. this is creating a core dependence on external packages.

core packages are ones we will continue to provide in whisk.system, do you disagree?

@rabbah So the course of action should be to document the installation steps for open (not deliver the .sh files to open at all). The installation steps will be: 1. Run git clone https://github.com/openwhisk/wsk-pkg-pushnotifications.git "$dir" 2. Run the install.sh (pass in environment vars for API_HOST and AUTH_KEY) script from the clone.  For the tests, we would have a tests/build.gradle in the external package and a .travis.yml (in root dir of the package itself).
Closing Epic, as children issues for Swift are done

@markusthoemmes ,thank you. @rabbah, yes, correct, just a confirm of requirements. I'll add more implementations as commented by Carlos if I could. Now I'm more clear, Thank you.
@csantanapr , do you know if there is a sample you described that could create the daemon? for the github webhook.js seems delegate the job to github?
@csantanapr, thanks a lot.
@lehoanganh thanks, I like it... now we are clean in the deployment playbooks and have no database wipe or initdb included, everything must be done explicitly.
Database for entities continues to be wiped implicitly by the deployment process, right?
yes, that's correct. `wipe.yml` is called in jenkins and UCD flows directly. In UCD we additionally introduce a process flag `doWipe=true/false` for `deployTest`.
So we have to delete the subjects database manually, while we have processes for the entities database, which is equally precious? That seems inconsistent to me.

`whisk` db can be wiped or not wiped, depends on which purpose

ci deployment: yes, fresh installation, wipe
dev development: yes and no, one can choose before each installation

`subjects` db is important, so it should not be dropped and recreated once it's already there cause it is potentially shared between multiple users

As a result of a more thorough discussion of the problem, we agreed to continue on the path layed out above.

Concerns included:
- Why would we tell the developer to delete subjects db manually, but deliver a process to delete the equally important entities database?
- This induces inconsistencies in the handling of those two databases.

Important to note is, that the subjects database can be shared in many environments, which raises the importance of not deleting it, even if the entities database is removed frequently.
@rabbah updated readme and squashed. pls review and merge.

If `wsk list` lists feeds, I as a user expect to be able to do something like `wsk feed get` as I can do that with all the other entities. That'ld strenghten @mbehrendt 's point of having feeds as first-class entities, at least on CLI level.

the current blackbox test exists but it does not actually download the sdk from nginx. I opened a separate issue to track this. similar problem with cli tests which also do not download. see blue issue 1971. should probably move to open.
depends on #580

current plan:
1. we want to get rid of dirty files in ansible/environments/local
2. issue #580 is going to make local envs read from a .gitignored ini file that is created during setup.yml
3. setup.yml defaults to couchdb but supports env variables used by vagrant such as OW_DB_USERNAME, OW_DB_PASSWORD etc.
4. once #580 is merged, this issue will change the vagrant files as follows:
- export OW_xxx variables I got from the user if any
- ansible-playbook setup.yml (this writes a db_local.ini file to /ansible containing the creds)
- ansible-playbook couch.yml (if no OW_xxx stuff set. instead of start-couchdb-box.sh)
- ansible-playbook initdb.yml (instead of createImmortalDB.sh, now changed so that it never drops)
- ant build deploy (ant deploy changed so that it runs ansible-playbook openwhisk.yml)

It looks like http_proxy is something that the golang http library handles, user can use both HTTP_PROXY or http_proxy

If we use the golang net http library to connect to openwhisk API it should be easy to implement, but as always we will need to write some test cases to have confident in the integration.

This couchdb service is installed on the same machine, where openwhisk is installed. They can be accessed via 127.0.0.1:5984.
172.0.0.1:5984 is not valid inside the whisk containers. Use the Vagrant host ip instead.
We have legal clearance to create the package/action, but not to externalize it yet. We must expose the need for the customer to have an ID of their own.
We have a few regression tests that check that the swagger matches the behavior.   We probably need many more such tests.
duplicate/related to #270 (which has several related issues linked).

@browezilla let's clarify what does "but not to externalize", I think we are OK here since how packages are not going to be install by default, user will be the one to install the package in openwhisk.

Installing the senGrid package in a comercial offering of openwhisk like bluemix, it's up to that company (i.e. IBM) to make the decision if they want to install the package in their production openwhisk for their customers.

For now the developer doing this work, I suggest follows the same pattern as [openwhisk/wsk-pkg-pushnotifications](https://github.com/openwhisk/wsk-pkg-pushnotifications) and make it public here in opensource. We can create a new repo (i.e. openwhisk/openwhisk-package-email)

We just need to like business as usual that any code or 3rd party libraries are compatible with the main openwhisk one Apache 2.0 (https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/LICENSE.txt) License

Wow, 127.0.0.1:5984 does not work, but if I switch the IP to something else like 192.168.0.23:5984, the build and deploy processes will succeed.
I am able to create the action and call the action. However, when I tried to run "wsk action list", it showed me:

vagrant@vagrant-ubuntu-trusty-64:~$ wsk action list
error: Unexpected http response code: 500 Internal Server Error (code 57)

I'll take a wild guess that you didn't install the couch views correctly: See https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/tree/master/tools/db#using-couchdb
- the CouchDB instance must set `reduce_limit` on views to `false` (see [this](https://github.com/openwhisk/openwhisk/blob/master/tools/db/couchdb/createAdmin.sh#L55) for how to do this via REST)
